docs.lead_paragraph: When elderly stroke victims go home, their care is usually provided by family members, most often a spouse. But that can be a daunting task, and can often undermine the health of the person providing the care. A new study from Britain indicates that providing a few hours of formal nursing training can reduce that burden, as well as improve the patients' quality of life, and lower costs.
docs.abstract: Dr Lalit Kalra, King's College, London, researcher, leads study published in journal BMJ indicating that brief formal nursing training for family of stroke victims is beneficial for patient and family (S)
docs.snippet: When elderly stroke victims go home, their care is usually provided by family members, most often a spouse. But that can be a daunting task, and can often undermine the health of the person providing the care.    A new study from Britain indicates...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who spend long hours in the summer sun have an increased risk later in life of developing an eye disease that can cause blindness, researchers have found. But sunglasses and hats that shade the eyes can prevent some of the damage. The disease, age-related maculopathy, is the leading cause of vision loss in older people in the United States. Scientists think people who develop the disease may have a genetic predisposition to it, brought out by an environmental exposure to something like sunlight. As the population ages, the number of people who are blind or suffering from impaired vision from the disease is expected to increase significantly, according to the National Eye Institute.

headline.main: Summer Sun Can Put Older Eyes at Risk, Study Says

docs.abstract: National Eye Institute predicts that as population ages number of people who are blind or have impaired vision will increase sharply; Sandra C Tomany, University of Wisconsin Medical School researcher, directs study linking extended exposure to sunlight to eye damage later in life; age-related maculopathy is leading cause of vision loss in United States (M)
docs.snippet: People who spend long hours in the summer sun have an increased risk later in life of developing an eye disease that can cause blindness, researchers have found. But sunglasses and hats that shade the eyes can prevent some of the damage.    The...

docs.lead_paragraph: How tall is your child? Don't ask your pediatrician. A new study found that only 30 percent of height measurements taken in primary care practices were accurate. The average mistake was half an inch, and one measurement was off by almost five inches. But the accuracy rates more than doubled with training.
docs.abstract: Dr Terri H Lipman of University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing leads study on pediatric practice of measuring children; finds that only 30 percent of doctor's offices sets accurate height of children; accuracy rate rises to 70 percent after providing up-dated equipment and training; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: How tall is your child? Don't ask your pediatrician. A new study found that only 30 percent of height measurements taken in primary care practices were accurate.    The average mistake was half an inch, and one measurement was off by almost five...

docs.lead_paragraph: Biologically speaking, the ideal age at which to have a baby is between 18 and 20. That is when pregnancy is most likely to produce a healthy full-term child with the least risk to the health of the mother. Considered from an evolutionary perspective, this makes sense too, since a child born to an 18-year-old would reach independence when the mother was 36. That mother would then live another 10 or so years to help out with the grandchildren, fostering the perpetuation of the species. Today, however, millions of American women are postponing marriage and childbearing until their mid- to late-30's, the age at which our forebears became grandparents. Currently in this country, one in five women has her first child after 35.

headline.main: The Risks and Demands of Pregnancy After 20

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses risks associated with pregnancy for women over age of 20; suggests that older women need to be aware of potential complications and prepare for possible disappointment if they cannot become pregnant; Dr Shirley Fong and Dr Peter McGovern of University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey's Department of Obstetrics Gynecology and Women's Health publish study in journal Contemporary Ob/Gyn that explains some reasons why older women have more trouble becoming pregnant and sustaining healthy pregnancy; one third of women in early 40's experience miscarriage compared to 10 percent in women under 30; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pharmacies in minority areas of Michigan are only half as likely as pharmacies in mainly white neighborhoods to stock many pain medications, a study has found. The study was presented on Friday at an American Pain Society meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia, by its lead author, Dr. Carmen R. Green of the University of Michigan.
docs.abstract: Dr Carmen R Green, University of Michigan researcher speaking to meeting of American Pain Society, reports that pain killers are less likely to be available at pharmacies in minority areas; survey, distributed randomly to pharmacies, asked about 15 different pain medications; 90 percent of pharmacies in predominantly white areas met criteria for adequate supply, but only 51 percent of pharmacies in minority areas met criteria; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Pharmacies in minority areas of Michigan are only half as likely as pharmacies in mainly white neighborhoods to stock many pain medications, a study has found.    The study was presented on Friday at an American Pain Society meeting in Vancouver,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Debra and Patrick Doyle of Aspen, Colo., go skiing every weekend in the winter and, in summer, take long mountain bike rides in the hilly terrain where they live. What helps this 36-year-old couple feel so energetic?

headline.main: It's Fizzy and the Can is Nice, But Coffee May Be Cheaper

docs.abstract: Australian company that manufactures Red Bull, trendy beverage that claims to boost energy and improve athletic performance, holds that 1.5 billion cans of drink were sold in 2003; drink contains as much caffeine as cup of brewed coffee, but has many more calories and two tablespoons of added sugar; price of Red Bull can range from slightly less than $2 to as high as $8 for drink in bars; critics question if drink benefits athletes or just gives consumer caffeine and sugar rush with some vitamins; photos; drawing; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Debra and Patrick Doyle of Aspen, Colo., go skiing every weekend in the winter and, in summer, take long mountain bike rides in the hilly terrain where they live.    What helps this 36-year-old couple feel so energetic?

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Underage and Overweight,'' by Frances M. Berg. Hatherleigh Press, $24.95. ''Our Overweight Children,'' by Sharron Dalton. University of California Press, $24.95.
docs.abstract: Francis M Berg book Underage and Overweight provides statistics on epidemic of childhood obesity in United States; advises that intake of food should become routine and mealtimes should be dictated by parent; describes possible reasons for weight crisis among young people; Sharron Dalton book Our Overweight Children holds that 15 percent of American children are overweight and another 15 percent are at risk of adult ailments associated with obesity; admits that helping children maintain healthy weights is complex problem; photos (M)
docs.snippet: ''Underage and Overweight,'' by Frances M. Berg. Hatherleigh Press, $24.95.    ''Our Overweight Children,'' by Sharron Dalton. University of California Press, $24.95.

docs.lead_paragraph: Leigh Todd spent four years and $300,000 to have a baby. She saw 10 doctors and sought help at medical clinics in New York, Chicago and Las Vegas. And while Ms. Todd says she had no idea what she was in for when she began her quest, it did not take long before she was sucked into a world of tests and treatments, conventional and unconventional, doing whatever it took, paying as much as was asked.
docs.abstract: Number of assisted fertility attempts in United States has risen from 64,036 in 1996 to 107,587 in 2001 and fertility experts hold that increased options for infertile couples is part of reason; cost of treatments vary with in vitro fertilization using donor eggs running as high as $35,000 per attempt; there is concern that patients, desperate to have children, are vulnerable and often try even unproven methods to get pregnant; Leigh Todd's story of quest for baby discussed; Dr Mark V Sauer of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons contends that patients are basically well-informed about procedures and options; graph showing costs of various fertility options; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Antibiotics can reduce the effectiveness of birth control. THE FACTS -- This rumor dates from the early 1970's, when doctors started documenting reports of women who were taking both the pill and antibiotics, and became pregnant. For the most part, experts now say, such cases can be attributed to chance.
docs.abstract: Study, conducted in 1997, dispels long-held belief that taking antibiotics can reduce effectiveness of birth control pills; powerful antibiotic rifampin, which is not commonly used, is only antibiotic found to possibly interfere with birth control pills; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: THE CLAIM -- Antibiotics can reduce the effectiveness of birth control.    THE FACTS -- This rumor dates from the early 1970's, when doctors started documenting reports of women who were taking both the pill and antibiotics, and became pregnant. For...

docs.lead_paragraph: With each of their first four attempts at in vitro fertilization, Heather and Eric Wulfsberg saw their hopes rise, only to watch them plunge when the treatments failed. ''The first time, the disappointment is worst, but it's amazing how much optimism bubbles up out of you every time,'' Ms. Wulfsberg said. ''Every time we got disappointing news, it would just knock the wind out of us.''

headline.main: For Couples, Stress Without a Promise of Success

docs.abstract: Seeking infertility treatment is often mentally and physically challenging for couple; Dr Brennan Peterson, Chapman University, California, assistant psychology professor, leads study of 618 couples, 525 of them infertile, in which he asesses impact of trying to start family; study, published in journal Family Process, finds that women feel pressure more than men and are more likely to seek physician's assistance to get pregnant; process of trying to conceive and different treatments are stressful on couple, family and friends; report, however, shows that more than 90 percent of couples studied expressed average or above average marital satisfaction; photo (M)
